ACTION TAKEN. Control of Supplies and Prices.Allied Purchases.-Negotiations have been conducted by the Treasury and the Ministry of Food Avith Mr. Crosby and with the United States Treasury with a view-to arranging finance required for the purchase of the additional 35,000 tons of frozen meat, which Mr. Owen Smith estimates are available, and the 150,000,000 pounds of pork products, which Mr. Hoover is now in a position to export, and which were the subject of cablegrams contained in last week's Report.Lord Rhondda has cabled to Mr. Hoover as follows : " Unless you are able to send the Allies at least seventy-five million bushels of wheat over and above what you have exported up to January first and in addition to ihe total exportable surplus from Canada I cannot take the responsibility of assuring our people that there will be food enough to win the war. Imperative necessity compels me to cable you in this blunt way. No one knows better than I that the American people, regardless of national and individual sacrifice, have so far refused nothing that is needed for the Avar, but it now lies Avith America to decide whether or not the Allies in Europe shall have enough bread to hold out until the United States is able to throw its force into the field. I have not minced Avords because I am convinced that the American people if they knoAv the truth will not hesitate to - meet the emergency.". ,.: Mr. Owen Smith cables that up to the 29th of December his total commitments on Government account for meats, fats, oleo oil, neutral lard, and dried fruits amounted to 85,844,000 dollars... Allotments bave been received from the United States Food Administration of 24,820,000 pounds of frozen beef for delivery up to 28th February, and contracts have been closed in Canada for 1,929,445 pounds of frozen beef.As there is a probability of supplies of butter being available in Siberia during the coming season, inquiry is being made as to the possibility of the United States and Canada releasing large quantities of butter from their East Coast for shipment to this country in the event of similar shipments being made from Vladivostok to the West Coasts of the United States and Canada.Mr. Owen Smith has been instructed that in the event of shipping space bein^ available for articles of food of secondary importance, the folloAving is the order of priority: -(1) Canned fish. (2) Dried fruit, (3) Eggs. (4) Canned fruit. (5) Dried fish.Bacon, Hams and Lard. The position in regard to these commodities is uoav very serious. On account of the extremely small December shipments the January arrivals will, it is anticipated, be about 10,000 tons, Avhich is less than the full requirements of the Army alone for one month. The latest completed Monthly Returns, however, show that home production was.slightly in excess of the amount which this -Ministry on other data had anticipated for the rjeriod. It is -proposed if on further examination by this Ministry and the Military Authorities it proves practi-cable, to requisition some home produced supplies for the Army, in order to release some of the imports for distribution for civilian consumption.The cause of the shortage is not quite clear ; six large liners leaving the United States of America between..the.12th. December, 1917J and the 9th January, 1918 carried only 760 tons of bacon, hams and lard altogether. Preliminary proposals for the control of home produced supplies have been formulated, and a Conference with the bacon curers has been arranged for the 18th January, 1918.A deputation of wholesalers has been received to consider further control of the price of cooked hams.Butter and Cheese. A further purchase of nearly 250 tons of butter has-been made in the United States of America by the Inter-Allied Meat and Fats Executive Mission; approximately, the total so purchased is now 1,450 tons. The price is 44 cents per lb., f.a.s. in New York.The current prices for Dutch, cheese have been extended for the present, but will be reviewed by the Food Controller about the 31st March, 1918.CereaLs. Arrangements have been completed by which the Wheat Export Co. shall allocate to shippers the shipment of cereals from the United States to British West Africa and West Indian Colonies as licensed by the United States Food Administration.The Wheat Export Co. have been instructed to hold 30,000 tons of wheat at the disposal of. the Swiss Government for January loading pending a final decision as to the arrangements for future supply of that country.The Wheat Export Co. have been instructed to furnish 50,000 tons of wheat monthly to the Commission for Relief in Belgium, and the American Food Admini-stration have increased the monthly allocation of cereals to the Wheat Export Co. by a like quantity.The RovalCommission have secured 10,000 tons of Irish oats. "'' " It has been decided to. fix a maximum price of Ad. per lb. for Burma rice and (id. per lb. for all other rices, a condition of sale being- that the better quality rice should not be offered unless the cheaper rice was also on sale. '.'In order to encourage the use of potatoes in bread the limit of 121 per cent, admixture of potatoes has been removed, ;and a communication has been issued to the Press informing the trade that the Ministry of Food is likely to issue an Order making the use of potatoes in bread compulsory. Priority certificates have been alreadj^ secured for 3,700 machines, half of which have already been sold.The Wheat (Seed) Order, 1918, dated 10 January ,191,8, is designed to ensure farmers obtaining a. plentiful supply of suitable seed wheat for the extensive spring sowing that is anticipated. Until further notice no person in any part of the United Kingdom may use for purposes other than seed any wheat of the varieties White Marvel, Red Marvel, and April Bearded grown in the British Islands, or in Ireland the variety known as Red Fife. While the restriction is in force no one may buy or acquire wheat of. these varieties unless he ordinarily deals in them and obtains them for re-sale as seed, or requires them for the purpose of seed. Holders of stocks may not dispose of them except to persons coming in the above categories.The Order does not apply to wheat which . shall be determined to be unfit for seed by any person authorised by the Food Controller or by any of the three Departments of.Agriculture.Meat-fhe Sheep (Sales) Order, 1918, dated January 15th, 1918, has been issued, requiring all sheep for slaughter to be sold and bought in a market, and to be valued at a market, or some other authorised collecting centre, by a Valuation Committee appointed by the Area Live Stock Commissioner, or by a person authorised to grade in their place. The value of the sheep is to be ascertained on the basis of the dressed weight of the carcase as estimated by the Valuation Committee and assessed at the rate of Is. 2\d. per lb., including the offals ; the worth of the skin is to be taken at its current, market value. The owner of. the sheep will have the option of selling the sheep at the same rate on the actual deadweight based to be ascertained within 12 hours after slaughter. In this case the sheep must be sent to a special Govern-ment depot, where it will be slaughtered at an authorised Government slaughterhouse. The auctioneer members of Valuation Committees and Wholesale Meat Supply Associations may appoint a limited number of sheep dealers to act as agents, at a remuneration of not more than 9d. per head, plus costs. As in the case of cattle, a "per head" charge on every sheep sold for slaughter will be received by the Government authorised agent; this charge of 5s. will cover auctioneer^ charges, market tolls, valuation, railage, slaughtering charges, droving from market to railway and from railway to slaughterhouse, and various other expenses. Of this sum, Is. Qd. Will be deducted from the farmer's price, and 3s. 6d. will be paid by the buyer to the Government authorised agent. In order to cover this charge on the buyer; a licence lias been issued increasing the maximum wholesale price of mutton and lamb of Qd. per stone.The Edible Offals (Maximum Price) Order limits the wholesale and retail prices of home-killed and imported offals; where offals are sold by wholesale, delivery is included, and in the case of retail sale no additional charge may be made for packages or for giving credit or making delivery.The Meat (Retailers' Restriction) Order prohibits any retail butcher from purchasing in any one week a greater number of cattle or quantity of meat than is prescribed in his case for that week under the authority of the Food Controller. Similarly, he cannot sell by retail in any week a greater quantity of meat than may be so prescribed. The Food Controller may thus revise the butcher's quota from week to week. During the next few weeks the butchers are being restricted to 50 per cent, of their October standard.Milk. The Milk (Registration of Dealers) Order, 1918, dated 8th January 1918, prohibits any person, other than a producer, from dealing in milk after February 9th, 1918, unless he holds, or has applied for, a licence from the Food Controller autho-rising him to do so. The Order also prohibits any person from dealing in milk by retail after February 23rd, 1918, unless he holds a certificate of registration granted by his Local Food Control Committee.Sugar. The situation as regards provision of tonnage remains very unsatisfactory in the West as well as in the East.Negotiations for the handling of Government-bought tea are still pro-ceeding. Outstanding points have been practically settled with the English Wholesale Distributing Trades both in London and the Provinces. A few questions still await settlement with the Scottish and Irish wholesalers.The question of permitting for Government-bought tea in Ireland a higher price than the uniform price fixed for Great Britain is being considered by this Ministry and the Food Control Committee for Ireland. .It is not thought that there will be serious opposition to the policy of having a single grade of tea.Owing to the great congestion at the Liverpool Docks it is not certain that the wholesale distribution of Government-bought tea can begin at the beginning of February as had been anticipated. Five ships carrying tea entered Liverpool though this Ministry had tried to arrange that two or three should go to Manchester. The weather is hampering the handling of tea at the docks, but an effort is being made to secure the assistance of military labour.Transport and Cold Storage. In the House of Commons on January 16th, Mr. Clynes stated that at the outbreak of war the approximate amount of refrigerated space and various cold-air stores throughout the United Kingdom was estimated at 28,000,000 cubic feet net, and that this had recently been increased hy approximately 3,500,000 cubic feet. The estimated amount of further increase expected during the first half of the current year was 6,100,000.. . Local Authorities.Reports generally still show that a serious shortage of meat, margarine, tea, and cheese, exists.The rationing of meat supplies by reference to the October quotas is said to work out unfairly in some places, eg., in Edinburgh, owing to the number of soldiers and American sailors on leave in the city.In the Newcastle area the trouble arising from a shortage of beer is again pointed out, and it is suggested that the difficulty be met by the allocation of larger supplies for the consumption of working men. The Commissioner for the Home Counties Division reports that the question of supply needs careful watching, otherwise strikes and riots may result, The shortage of meat in certain parts of Scotland is referred to by the Commissioner for the Eastern Division as amounting to a meat famine.Distribution. A new section of the Ministry of Food has been formed for the purpose.of dealing with local schemes of distribution. It is now fully occupied in examining the details of submitted schemes, in grouping related areas and sanctioning any proposal which promises to restore some degree of normal and equitable distribution. The following is a list of the most important grouped areas, for. which schemes-are in an advanced stage of preparation : (1) London and the Home Counties, aggregating districts with a population equal to nearly one-third of the country.(2) South West Midlands, with Birmingham as a centre. (3) The Tyneside District, with Newcastle as a centre. (4) The Cleveland District, with Middlesbrough as a centre. (5) North East Derbyshire, with Chesterfield as a centre.Proposals will shortly be submitted to the Ministry for the adoption of similar groups for the Manchester and Salford, Mersey side, Glasgow, South Wales, Teesdale and other large individual areas.Local schemes, which will probably rapidly develop into area schemes, are working or are about to come into operation at Sheffield, Leicester, Derby, Halifax, Nottingham, Rochdale, the Hartlepools, Peterborough, Reading, Bath, Cambridge and other places.Every scheme submitted includes butter and margarine in its proposed rationed foodstuffs ; other articles proposed to be included by particular districts are tea, meat, bacon, cheese and lard.Enforcement.The following cases of special interest have occurred during the week : -At Dublin, Messrs. W. L. Ryan & Co., Ltd., Wholesale Tea Merchants, were charged with having on the 3rd October sold, by traveller, 125 lbs. tea, at 4s. Qd. per lb., and also 122 lbs. of tea at the same price on another occasion. A fine of 10Z. in each of the two cases was imposed.Messrs. Regan & Co., Ltd., were also fined 20Z. for selling 247 lbs. of tea at &d. per lb. in excess of maximum.At the Penge Police Court, Charles Powell, licensee of the Palace Brewery, Anerley, and John K. Powell, a partner, were summoned for breAving 282 barrels of beer in excess for the quarter ended June 30th last, and 333 barrels of beer in excess for the quarter ended September 30th. H. Spurrier, manager, Avas summoned for aiding and abetting.The two partners were each fined 501. on each summons, making 2001. in all, AArith 25 guineas costs. The manager AA^as fined 101. on each summons.At the Marylebone Police Court, the Author's Hotel, Ltd., proprietors of the Wigmore Hotel, in Lower Seymour Street, Port-man Square, and Reginald Harris, the managing director of the hotel, were fined 30L with 3 guineas costs, a total of 66L 6s., for failing to keep a register of meals and food as required by the Public Meals Order.At Conway the Star Tea Company were fined IL for selling \ lb. of coffee above the fixed price through their local manager.At Newcastle Borough Police Court, Mr. Frederick Harrison, Headmaster of Newcastle High School, was summoned for unlawfully acquiring sugar, on six occasions, in excess of the quantity required for ordinary consumption in his household. A fine of 501., with 201. costs, AAras imposed.At Ingleton Petty Sessions, John Henry Gorril, Bentham, A\ras fined 101. and 1Z. 11s. costs for having 1 lb. 11 ozs. of bread in the swill tub.At Merthyr, Messrs. Wm. Harris Avere fined 501. for buying butter from the Lakelands Dairy Co., Ireland, at a price exceeding the maximum.At Marlborough Police Court, Messrs. Selfridge & Co., Ltd., were fined 10Z. and 21. costs for selling "Blue Band" margarine at a price exceeding the maximum. PART II.-SUMMARY OF THE"FOOD POSITION,The two most prominent features recorded in the following paragraphs and the tables are the alteration in the rate of - consumption of bread and flour during the four weeks ended January 5th, and the figures relating to the supply and consumption of meat from the beginning of December or more generally from September onward.The former is dealt with below, where it is pointed out that the decrease in the rate of consumption as compared with that of the previous period amounts to 3^ per cent., but that in the corresponding period of last winter there was a decrease of 7 per cent.; under the circumstances it would be incorrect to assame that the decrease in the four weeks which ended January 5th, 1918, points to a decline in consumption which is likely to continue. The special circumstances of Christmas time appear to offer some explanation.Allusion was made in previous Reports to the nature of the scarcity in the meat supply. The account.now given suggests some improvement, but it must be pointed out that the temporary remedy, namely, the increase in the sheep coming into market, may lead to stibsequent reaction and to some reduction in the future supplies of mutton. The history of the movement which has now assumed an acute phase can be traced in the returns from slaughterhouses (Table D), and the market records of previous months (Table 0), which combine to show the heavy pressure on the supply of home-fed meat. This was accentuated by recent circumstances set out last week.Imports.The aggregate weight of imports of principal foods (including rice and tea) was 135,000 tons in the week ending January 12th (Table A), as compared with 142,000 tons in the corresponding week last year. Though this is less than last week, it is -21,000 tons more than the average of the previous fortnight, and 17,000 tons more than the average of the previous four weeks.The imports of wheat and.flour, meat, bacon, &c, cheese, sugar and tea did not differ much from the average of the previous four weeks.As compared with the corresponding week last year, sugar shows an increase of 3,200 tons, bacon and hams a decrease of 2,400 tons and cheese a decrease of 1,600 tons ; the quantities of wdieat and flour, meat and tea were nearly the same in the second weeks of 1917 and 1918.Oereals other than wheat show considerable, variations : Thousand tons.. The supplies of home-fed meat at four principal meat markets (Table B) for the week ended January 5th were 16 per cent, less than in the previous week and 37 per cent, below those of the corresponding week last year. At Smithfield in the week ended January 12th there was an improvement, but the supply was still 30 per cent, below last year.The supply of fat cattle at 59 markets, though 6 per cent, better than the week before (the. first to which the new Order applied), was only 28 per cent, of the supplya 4703-3 10 last year (Table C). As a partial compensation the supply of sheep was abnormally great and 5.2 per cent, above last year. The actual excess was 36,900 sheep, while the defect of cattle was 12,100 battle.The supply of pigs at these markets no longer affords a good indication of the general supply, and the: figures from the slaughter-house returns are used in the' place of ihe market returns for pigs in. computing the index-numbers of consumption in Table E. . The supply of- imported meat at four principal-markets (Table B) in the week ended January 5th was 990 tons more than in the previous week, and 10 per cent:; above the average for December, 1917, but the aggregate supply of home-fed and imported meat was 38 per cent, below last year. An improvement of 260 tons imported meat is reported at Smithfield in the week ended January 12th. -Bread and Flour.-The returns of flour Used or sold by bakers and retailers for the four weeks ended January 5th are nearly complete. They show a reduction of SI- per cent, over the previous four weeks, but an increase of 2 per cent, over the corre-sponding weeks a year ago (Table E). Last year the reduction in the period covering Christmas was 7 per cent. The reduction both years is no doubt due to increased consumption of other foods at Christmas time; this year other foods were not available in their usual quantities, and it is reasonable to assume that less bread and flour were saved from this cause. The saving this year was one days' consumption; last year it was two days'. In addition to the seasonal change the shortage of meat; margarine and butter occurred during the four weeks in question, and it is remarkable that the increase in the consumption of flour over last year should have been so small.For these reasons the index-numbers for these weeks should not be considered as indicating the commencement of a downward trend in consumption.Table L shows that the movement has not been uniform throughout the country. In particular, in the Home Counties and the South Midlands the reduction in consumption of bread between the four weeks to December 8th and the four to January 6th has been very slight, perhaps because of a more acute shortage of other foods in this part of England than elsewhere.The following table shows the position of bakers"' and retailers' stocks.
